captions.text:
How can you do business
with this guy?

I want no further
conflict with him.

He can live,
or he can die.

He can't be
doing this alone.

Just when I
thought I was out,

Has not yet
shown his face.

I don't know
what he took.

comments.text:
Am I the only one who thinks the personality, the behaviour, etc of Michael 
seems to be much more different that part 2? I mean he was a bleak sort of 
cold guy, a dark hearted man and stuff. Here, he is a bit more, lets say, 
colorful, has more positive energy and lighter nature wise. I guess age 
changed him.﻿
comments.author: saad afzal

comments.text: +SantomPh And then it got taken from him.
comments.author: Shanethefilmmaker

comments.text:
+saad afzal he developed health problems that damaged him on many levels, 
but more importantly Connie was true to her word and took care of him, 
giving him the family he always wanted. His daughter Mary grew up to be a 
source of joy in his life, and he also reconnected with Kay, who he still 
loved after all this time.

His biggest relief was that he had shed most of the criminal side of the 
Corleone Empire, leaving New York altogether for Nevada together will all 
the pain it had caused his family. His deal with the Vatican was meant to 
make him really happy and hopefully redeemed. For once Mike has optimism in 
his eyes.
comments.author: SantomPh

comments.text:
+saad afzal Well when you get old your attitude on life changes. When 
Michael Corleone started out he was an innocent law abiding citizen. Then 
part 2 he became worse than Sonny and Vito combined. Now all he has left 
are the people he loves and he's trying his hardest to keep them from 
slipping away.
comments.author: Shanethefilmmaker

comments.text:

comments.author: ThePsychoticEnigma

comments.text:
+ThePsychoticEnigma The only reason why I even decided to watch the first 
two films back in 1997 on the USA Network was because I saw this particular 
scene while I was channel surfing one night listening to The Police 
Greatest Hits cassette tape on my headphones. It was amazing acting and the 
cinematography was incredible. This movie was airing on Sunday night CBS 
Movie, and the second part was shown on Tuesday night.
comments.author: Mark Wright

comments.text:
+eris martin You should try reading the book "Introduction to Film 
Criticism" by Tim Bywater and Tomas Sobchack. They detail your view on art 
in the section known as "humanistic criticism", which most certainly 
exists. You're also taking the word "humanistic" too literally in this 
context.

Also, art is not an inherently positive term. Don't call something art 
because you think it is good. Art is just the byproduct of human 
creativity. It can be good, or it can be bad. Pulp Fiction is art, and if 
you don't like it, say it's "bad art" don't say it's not art. The 
definition of art should not be subjective.

Pulp Fiction is "art" because it's a film, which is an art form, and thus 
all films are art. To say otherwise is to be pretentious. The 
cinematography, the characters, the post-modern approach to crime films and 
noir, etc, that's what gives Pulp Fiction depth and worth. Like I said, 
your view of art is myopic and needs to be expanded. You can't declare 
something as "not art" simply because you're unable to view it from 
different angles beyond how it emotionally affects you. And stop applying 
the word literature to film.
comments.author: EvTav

comments.text:
+EvTav I dont believe there is any such thing as "Humanistic critcism" and 
if there was if, it's defintiton would not be as you've stated it; it would 
be something that affirms the importance or special characteristics of 
humans. Also, that was not my only def; and I dont attempt to squeeze 
things into the def of literture, the def comes after. I didnt say: does 
pulp fiction do thus and thus, before I decided if it was art.

And I also make a distinction between movie like wolf of wall street or 
pulp fiction and a tarkovsky film. the first two are well made, but I dont 
consider them art(but I also use the word art in a sort of arbritary way)

But, by all means, tell me how pulp fiction is art. since "i need to learn" 
and all.
comments.author: eris martin

comments.text:
There are many different forms of criticism. The way that you are viewing 
"literature" is actually called humanistic criticism. There's nothing wrong 
with it, but to only consider something "literature" if it fits within 
those boundaries is an incredibly myopic way of viewing art. You need to 
learn that there are other ways to value and appreciate a work of art 
beyond how it comments on the human condition.
comments.author: EvTav

comments.text:
+christopher399 the way I break up the two categories is : literature has 
the ability to change your perspective on life, leave you almost awestruck, 
make you contemplate on the character or point of the novie, or the novie 
makes some social comment or comment on the human condition(comment on the 
human condition may be the best way to sum it up) sometimes even complex 
and psychological deep characters is enough. While others may have good 
writing,acting etc, but don't do what I stated above. 

Maybe another way to say it is: if you can look back on a movie and feel 
like you really wouldn't have ever missed out on it, then its literature ( 
of course it's possible with something like 'rounders' If that movie drove 
you to become a successful poker player, but I think it's easy enough to 
tell the difference) 

Nothing in pulp fiction could have given me the same feeling as when in 
citizen Kane you finally learned what Kanes lasts words meant.
comments.author: eris martin

comments.text:
+eris martin I didn't feel like you were trying to tell me which one to 
like the most.

comments.text: Why did he yell "FREDO" at the end?﻿
comments.author: karthu1993

comments.text:
+fezzat at the time he thought it was the only way to tie up a loose end. 
However as time went on he realized he made a massive mistake and killed 
his brother, something even real mafioso shudder at. That act tore him away 
from his own son, who loved Fredo.

Fredo, out of all the deaths he has caused haunts him the most as he never 
actually took the time to get to know his own older brother (like he 
basically ignored Anthony) and make him happy, if not useful. They are real 
brothers-and yet no one bar Connie treated him like one.

Fredo didn't want to get Mike killed- he just blabbed information to Hyman 
Roth, which Roth used to get to Mike and his family. He was a fool to trust 
Roth and should have gone to Michael for help. but as an outcast in the 
family, he probably didn't feel that much for the organization.
comments.author: SantomPh

comments.author: Round House

comments.text:
No. The third part is separate from the first two. Each character is shown 
in a completely different light from the first two parts. In the first two 
films, we see Michael stepping forward and becoming the leader. In the 
third film, you see him in decline.

Yes there are strong similarities between the third part and the first two, 
but they are not the same. The themes are different. The temper and tone of 
the film is different. The way it was filmed is different. The way it 
starts and ends is fundamentally different. It stands on it's own and 
punctuates the trilogy beautifully.

Above all, though, you cannot approach the third part with the same 
attitude as the first two parts. If you do, it's only a pale imitation.

You have to look at it as it's own entity... of course, this is all just my 
own opinion. You're certainly  not required to agree. :)
comments.author: Falcrist

comments.text:
The Godfather part 3 is not it own part. Part 3 test your your knowledge to 
see if you have been paying attention. In the scene above, Michael did now 
want to act Joey Zasa because true enemy is always hidden, as in part 1, 
and 2.  by going after zasa, Vincent and Connie make the same mistake Sonny 
made in part 1 (Zasa and Tattaglia, are the same enemy type, pawns sent in 
a someone else master plan). The same trickery that Don Corleone hatch in 
part 1 with luca, is the trickery Michael hatch with Vincent Corleone, why 
did luca  fail and Vincent succeed. I could go on but you need to figure 
these things out yourself. their are lots more.
comments.author: Round House

comments.text:
+Round House Godfather 1 and 2 are one story told in two parts. Godfather 3 
is it's own entity. I don't say that to condemn it, but if you view it as 
merely a continuation of the original, it's just not as good. You have to 
approach it with a different mindset to appreciate it.

It actually has a few really memorable moments, despite the mediocre 
acting. Michael's silent scream at the end is one of the most moving 
moments in cinema history (IMO). Overacting? Yes, but it works.
comments.author: Falcrist

comments.text:
+john jingleheimer The Godfather 1, 2, and 3 are not 3 separate movies, 
they are one movie told in three parts. Your statement shows that you are 
clueless to the chess game taking place in these movies.
comments.author: Round House

comments.text:

comments.author: john jingleheimer

comments.text:
+therobbieunited I think he has done some great things but acting should 
look like real life. It shouldn't look like you are acting. Just my 
observation. I know what I like to see as a consumer. This is always my 
yardstick "would I pay to see that" in movies, sports whatever. If the 
answer is "no" then it just doesn't cut it. Just an opinion. He is a stage 
actor and that is the style. You have to overact to get your point across 
on a big stage. I think his best work was his low-key style in the 
godfather I and II. He was also good in dog day afternoon, ...and justice 
for all and serpico. The rest is all crap as far as I'm concerned.
Again, just my opinion. His costar in a few movies, john cazale on the 
other hand was a FANTASTIC actor with his minimalistic style.
comments.author: Mik Lep

comments.author: mike Lewis

comments.text:
Stand alone, this is a SOLID film. As the finial part of this trilogy, it 
lacks CONSIDERABLY. However, it's much more emotionally driven than the 
other two films. It's a lot darker and cerebral. Seriously, watch it again. 
It's a deep, deep movie!

comments.author: greengun37

comments.text:
On it's own, Godfather III is an average crime film. Not particularly 
offensive. As the concluding part of a trilogy, it's sloppy and 
underwhelming. The first two films function in such perfect harmony, and 
then this cash-cow comes along sixteen years too late and screws the whole 
thing up.
